coredata.dc:title: Rational construction of Pt/PtTex interface with optimal intermediate adsorption energy for efficient hydrogen evolution reaction

coredata.dc:description: Increasing OH* adsorption to promote water dissociation while reducing H* adsorption to accelerate hydrogen generation kinetics is an effective solution to further improve the HER activity of Pt-based catalysts. Herein, we have successfully constructed a Pt/PtTex heterogeneous catalysis interface by electrochemical activation of PtTe2 nanorods (NRs). The reduction of H* adsorption and significant increase of OH* adsorption was observed on Pt/PtTex heterojunction via cyclic voltammetry method. Theoretical calculations indicate that Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) of H* is closer to 0.00 eV and ΔG of OH* decreased from 1.36 eV of Pt (111) to −0.40 eV of Pt/PtTex, which reinforces the experimental results. The rational modulation of adsorbed intermediates endows Pt/PtTex NRs with exceptionally lower Tafel slopes of 16 and 23 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes, which is among the best reported HER electrocatalysts.

Pt/PtTex heterojunctions
Hydrogen evolution reaction
Long-term stability

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Morphological and structural evolution of PtTe2 NRs before and after the CV scanning. (a) TEM image of PtTe2 NRs; (b) HRTEM image of PtTe2 NRs, the inset is the corresponding SAED image; (c) HAADF-STEM image and corresponding EDS elemental mappings of PtTe2 NRs; (d) CV curves of PtTe2 NRs after various cycles; (e) Side view of Pt/PtTex heterojunction structure model, blue balls are Pt atoms and orange balls are Te atoms; (f) TEM image of Pt/PtTex NRs; (g) HRTEM image of Pt/PtTex NRs, the inset is the corresponding SAED image; (h) HAADF-STEM image and corresponding EDS elemental mappings of Pt/PtTex NRs.

Crystal structure and chemical state characterization of Pt/PtTex NRs. (a) XRD pattern of PtTe2 NRs and Pt/PtTex NRs; (b) High-resolution XPS spectra of Pt 4f of PtTe2 NRs and Pt/PtTex NRs; (c) High-resolution XPS spectra of Te 3d of PtTe2 NRs and Pt/PtTex NRs.

Electrochemical properties of PtTe2 NRs, Pt/PtTex NRs and commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) in 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolytes. (a) Linear sweep voltammetry curves in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte for PtTe2 NRs, Pt/PtTex NRs and commercial Pt/C (20 wt%); (b) corresponding Tafel plots; (c) Comparison of the Tafel slope and overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 between Pt/PtTex NRs and recently reported noble-metal HER electrocatalysts in 1.0 M KOH; (d) Linear sweep voltammetry curves in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte for PtTe2 NRs, Pt/PtTex NRs and commercial Pt/C (20 wt%); (e) corresponding Tafel plots; (f) Comparison of the Tafel slope and overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 between Pt/PtTex NRs and recently reported noble-metal HER electrocatalysts in 0.5 M H2SO4; (g) The number of active sites and ECSA of Pt/PtTex NRs and Pt/C, which are calculated from the charges of CO stripping; (h) Chronopotentiometry tests of Pt/PtTex NRs and Pt/C in 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4.
(a-b) The mass activity of Pt/C and Pt/PtTex NRs in (a) 0.5 M H2SO4 and (b) 1.0 M KOH solutions; (c-d) TOF curves of Pt/C and Pt/PtTex NRs in (c) 0.5 M H2SO4 and (d) 1.0 M KOH.

Characterization of reaction intermediates and correlation with adsorption energy in DFT calculations. (a) Calculated Gibbs free energy of OH* adsorption; (b) Calculated Gibbs free energy of H* adsorption; (c) CO stripping voltammetry of Pt/PtTex NRs and Pt/C in 1.0 M KOH solution, the scan rate is 50 mV s−1, the solid curves is the stripping of a monolayer of CO in the first scan cycle, and the dash curves is the second scan cycle after the stripping of CO; (d) Plots of the potential of CO stripping peak obtained from the CV curves and Gibbs free energy of OH* adsorption calculated from DFT calculations; (e) CV curves of Pt/PtTex NRs and Pt/C in N2-saturated 0.5 M H2SO4 solution with a scan rate of 50 mV s−1; (f) Plots of the potential of Hupd desorption peak obtained from the CV curves and Gibbs free energy of H* adsorption calculated from DFT calculations.
pDOS of d orbital of Pt, 2p orbital of O in OH adsorbed on (a) Pt(111), (b) Site 1 of Pt/PtTex, (c) PtTe2 (101) and (d) Site 2 of Pt/PtTex.

head.ce:title: Rational construction of Pt/PtTex interface with optimal intermediate adsorption energy for efficient hydrogen evolution reaction

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Increasing OH* adsorption to promote water dissociation while reducing H* adsorption to accelerate hydrogen generation kinetics is an effective solution to further improve the HER activity of Pt-based catalysts. Herein, we have successfully constructed a Pt/PtTex heterogeneous catalysis interface by electrochemical activation of PtTe2 nanorods (NRs). The reduction of H* adsorption and significant increase of OH* adsorption was observed on Pt/PtTex heterojunction via cyclic voltammetry method. Theoretical calculations indicate that Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) of H* is closer to 0.00 eV and ΔG of OH* decreased from 1.36 eV of Pt (111) to −0.40 eV of Pt/PtTex, which reinforces the experimental results. The rational modulation of adsorbed intermediates endows Pt/PtTex NRs with exceptionally lower Tafel slopes of 16 and 23 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes, which is among the best reported HER electrocatalysts.

ce:section.ce:para: The interaction between intermediates and catalysis surface manipulates the reaction kinetics by affecting the generation of reactive species, adsorption/desorption process and the energy barriers of elementary steps [1–4]. Among these factors, the targeted modulation of adsorption/desorption behavior is directly correlated to reaction kinetics such as energy barrier and reaction rate and of vital importance to the achievement of high activity toward a specific reaction [5,6]. Taking hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) as an example, the adsorption energy of intermediate species onto the surface of electrocatalysts has a great impact on the performance of catalysts. In acidic media, Pt catalysts are considered as the state-of-the-art catalysts owing to their favorable Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of H* adsorption (ΔGH* = -0.09 eV) [7,8]. Optimization of its H* adsorption closer to the thermodynamically neutral state (ΔG = 0.00 eV) is an effective way to further improve its intrinsic activity but remains a major challenge. In alkaline media, the H* is generated via the sluggish water dissociation on Pt catalysts (Fig. S1), which is closely related to the inherent weak OH* adsorption of Pt (111) [9,10]. As a result, the HER activity of Pt catalysts decreases by two orders of magnitude in alkaline media compared to acidic media due to the high activation barrier [11].

In terms of Pt-based catalysts, ideal H* adsorption and the OH* adsorption can be effectively modulated via the rational design of the interfacial structure and the intimate contact guaranteed by bridging through common atoms at the interfaces could achieve excellent structural stability. Platinum ditelluride (PtTe2), a topological semimetal, has received much attention in electrocatalysis due to its special physical and chemical properties [14,15]. The layered structure and feasibility in chemical composition change endow PtTe2 with great potential in catalysis. It has been reported that Te in PtTe2 is easy to be etched by heat treatment and electrochemical etching process [16]. This property can be employed to tailor the coordination environment of Pt atoms and construct unique Pt/PtTex interfaces, which are vital for modulating the reaction intermediates in electrocatalytic reactions. Hence, we successfully constructed Pt/PtTex heterojunctions on Pt/PtTex nanorods (NRs) to realize the intermediates adsorption modulation and long-term stability. Both experimental and theoretical calculation results verify that such a well-designed Pt/PtTex interface structure reduces H* adsorption for better kinetics of hydrogen generation and enhances OH* adsorption capacity significantly for favorable water dissociation. Thus, these Pt/PtTex NRs exhibited excellent HER activity, with extremely lower Tafel slopes of 16 and 23 mV dec−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes, respectively, and long-term stability up to 30 h with no significant decay of activity.

Platinum (Ⅱ) acetylacetonate (Pt(acac)2, 97 %) and Nafion (5%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Potassium tellurite (K2TeO3, 99.5 %) was purchased from Aladdin reagent Inc. Poly (vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, average M.W. 58000, K15-19) was purchased from J&K Scientiﬁc Ltd. Ethylene glycol (C2H6O2, AR), carbohydrazide (CH6N4O, 98 %), and isopropanol (IPA, AR) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.

Typically, Pt(acac)2 (5.0 mg), K2TeO3 (6.0 mg), PVP (100.0 mg), C2H6O2 (20.0 mg) were dissolved in ethylene glycol (10.0 mL). Then, the mixture was magnetically stirred until a homogeneous solution was formed. After that, the homogeneous mixture solution was then transferred into a Teﬂon-sealed autoclave and maintained at 180 °C for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the PtTe2 NRs were collected by centrifugation and washed three times with ethanol/acetone solution.

The as-prepared PtTe2 NRs were dispersed in ethanol (10.0 mL) and then Vulcan XC-72 carbon powders were added to the above suspension. After sonication for 30 min, the PtTe2 NRs/C was collected by centrifugation and washed several times using ethanol/acetone solution. The obtained PtTe2 NRs/C was vacuum-dried for further use. To prepare Pt/PtTex NRs/C, 2.0 mg PtTe2 NRs/C was dispersed in the mixture solution containing 200 μL IPA and 5 μL Nafion (5 wt%) and then sonicated for 1 h to get the homogeneous ink. After that, 5 μL of the ink was cast onto the glassy carbon electrode (GCE) with a diameter of 5 mm and vacuum-dried. Finally, the Pt/PtTex NRs/C was prepared by cyclic voltammetry (CV) for certain cycles in 0.5 M H2SO4 at room temperature. The obtained Pt/PtTex NRs/C was scraped from the electrode by ultrasonication in ethanol, followed by centrifugation and vacuum-dry for further characterization. The mass fraction of Pt on the Pt/PtTex NRs/C was determined by ICP-OES measurement.

SEM analysis was performed on a Hitachi SU8010 microscope. Low-magnification TEM images were collected by a Hitachi HT7700 at an acceleration voltage of 120 kV. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), HAADF-STEM and EDS mapping were conducted on the FEI Tecnai F20 at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. XRD patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV operating at 40 kV and 20 mA with Cu Kα radiation. The inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was performed on a Perkin Elmer Optima OES 800. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) was recorded on an Escalab 250Xi spectrometer and XPS spectra were calibrated with the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV.

Electrochemical experiments were carried out on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation (Chenhua, Shanghai) using a three-electrode system. A Hg/HgO electrode (1.0 M KOH solution as electrolyte) and a Hg/Hg2SO4 (saturated K2SO4 solution as electrolyte) electrode serve as the reference electrode in 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolytes, respectively. A graphite electrode serves as the counter electrode. To prepare the working electrode, 2.0 mg catalyst was dispersed in the mixture solution containing 200 μL IPA and 5 μL Nafion (5 wt%) and then sonicated for 1 h to get the homogeneous ink. After that, 5 μL of the ink was cast onto the glassy carbon electrode (GCE) with a diameter of 5 mm and vacuum-dried. The mass loading of catalyst on the GCE was calculated to be 0.05 mg and the catalyst loading here for all samples is 0.25 mg cm−2 in each experiment. All the potentials here in 1.0 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolytes are referenced to the reversible hydrogen electrode by the Nernst equation of E(RHE) = E(Hg/HgO) + 0.059 pH + 0.095 V and E(RHE) = E(Hg/Hg2SO4) + 0.059 pH + 0.640 V, respectively. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was carried out with a scan rate of 5 mV/s to obtain the polarization curves. Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were collected over the frequency ranging from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz with an amplitude of the applied voltage of 5 mV.

The CO stripping experiments are generally used to determine the number of active sites and the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of Pt-based catalysts. And this method is based on the premise that CO adsorption on the Pt surface is single-layer adsorption. The experimental steps are as follows: The CO adsorption was realized by bubbling CO for 20 min in 1.0 M KOH solution. Then, the dissolved CO in the electrolyte was removed by bubbling N2 for 20 min. And the potential was kept at 0.1 V during the above two steps. Finally, the CO adsorbed on the catalyst was stripped by applying a cyclic voltammetry test (0∼1.2 V).
The number of active sites was calculated as follows: n = QCO/(2Fm), where QCO is the charge of CO stripping, F is the Faraday constant, and m is the metal mass loading.
The ECSA was calculated as follows: ECSA = QCO/(m × 420 μC cm−2), 420 μC cm−2 is the value for a saturated CO monolayer formation on active metal sites.

The turnover frequencies (TOFs, H2 s−1) were estimated as follows: TOF = I/(2Fnm), where I is the current (A) during the LSV measurement, 2 is the number of electrons required to form one molecular hydrogen.

The Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were performed in the Vienna Ab initio simulation package (VASP) with the Perdew-Burke-Emzerhof (PBE). The projector augmented wave (PAW) functional was selected as the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) to describe the electron-ion interactions. A plane-wave energy cutoff was set to 400 eV. And (5 × 5×1) and (2 × 2×1) Monkhoest-Pack k-point mesh were used for all samples during electronic structure calculation and the structure optimization, respectively. Geometry optimization was stopped when the total energy tolerance was converged to 1 × 10−5 eV and the force residue of the atom was less than 0.02 eV/Å. During the surface calculations, and the dipolar correction was included. The crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (COHP) calculation was performed on the LOBSTER code.

The slab model of commercial Pt/C catalysts was constructed by cleaving the bulk structure with the (111) surface. The 4 × 4 supercells were employed. Pt (111) model contains 4 metal atom layers. The vacuum layer was set as 15 Å to avoid inter-layer interactions, and the atoms in the bottom two layers were kept frozen while the remaining were allowed to relax during the slab calculations.

To build the model of Pt/PtTex heterojunction, a 4 × 4 supercell for Pt (111) and a 3 × 2 supercell for PtTe2 (101) were constructed, and then they are built as layers. The as-build Pt/PtTe2 layer was cleaved along the (001) direction. Then, a vacuum layer of 20 Å between slabs was added to avoid inter-layer interactions. The thickness of Pt (111) and PtTe2 (101) slab models were four atomic and two PtTe2 single layers, respectively. The two outermost atomic layers away from the interface for Pt (111) and three outermost atomic layers away from the interface for PtTe2 (101) were kept frozen and the remaining are relaxed during the calculation. The convergence test with respect to the number of layers of Pt (111) and PtTe2 (101) in the structure was conducted.

The d-band center (εd) was calculated by the following formula:

where ε is the energy referring to E-Fermi and nd(ε) is DOS projected onto d-states or different orbits of d-states.

The Gibbs free energy for each step of samples in HER at 0 V was defined as G = EDFT + ZPE – TSvib, where E is the DFT-optimized total energy, ZPE is the zero point energy, TSvib is calculated through the harmonic-oscillator approximation and used for the vibrational entropy corrections. The adsorption free energies of X (X = H, OH and H2O) on the surface are defined as: ΔG = GX/surface - Gsurface - GX, where GX/surface, Esurface, and GX are the total free energies of X adsorbed surfaces, clean surfaces and X in the gas phase, respectively. Moreover, the Gsurface = Esurface, GH = GH2/2, GOH = GH2O -GH.

The PtTe2 NRs were synthesized by a simple solvothermal method, where potassium tellurite (K2TeO3) and platinum (Ⅱ) acetylacetonate (Pt(acac)2) were employed as metal precursors and ethylene glycol ((CH2OH)2) was used as the solvent. As revealed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM), the as-synthesized products show the outline of hollow nanorods (Figs. 1 a and S2). The Pt/Te atomic ratio of the product is determined to be around 1:2 by both energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) (Pt/Te = 35.5:64.7) (Fig. S3a) and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) (Pt/Te = 32.9:67.1). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the product shows the typical peaks of PtTe2 (JCPDS No. 18-0977) and the broadening of peaks may be related to the small grain size of PtTe2 on the NRs (Fig. 2 a) [14,15]. These results demonstrate that hollow PtTe2 NRs have been successfully prepared. The precise micromorphology of PtTe2 NRs was investigated by high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). As shown in Fig. 1b, distinct lattice fringes are observed on the NRs, and the lattice spacing of 0.290 nm can be ascribed to the (101) planes of PtTe2 [14,16]. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of PtTe2 NRs exhibits some distinct diffraction rings, indicating its polycrystalline nature. Moreover, HAADF-STEM elemental mappings of PtTe2 NRs show that Pt and Te elements overlap well along the NRs, thus confirming the uniform distribution of these two elements on NRs (Fig. 1c).

Then, the PtTe2 NRs were subjected to electrochemical corrosion by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution to construct Pt/PtTex heterojunctions on the NRs. For the convenience of electrochemical treatment, the PtTe2 NRs were loaded onto VC-X72 carbon powders and the NRs were evenly distributed on the carbon and no aggregation was observed (Fig. S4). Then, CV scans were performed on the PtTe2 NRs to dissolve Te and rearrange Pt atoms to form Pt/PtTex heterojunctions. To monitor the electrochemical corrosion process of PtTe2 NRs, the changes of CV curves were recorded (Fig. 1d). The oxidation peak at approximately 1.1 V originates from the oxidation of Te, and the decrease in the peak current at this potential from the 1st to the 200th CV cycle indicates the dissolution of Te during the continuous CV scans [16,17]. The underpotential deposited (UPD) hydrogen peak between 0.05 and 0.30 V on the 200th CV curve indicates that Pt atoms rearranged and formed Pt nanoparticles on the NRs [2,18]. The PtTe2 NRs after electrochemical activation with 200 CV scans were named Pt/PtTex NRs and characterized in detail. Compared with the pristine PtTe2 NRs, the TEM image of the Pt/PtTex NRs shows shrinkage in morphology and this surface reconstruction may be caused by the dissolution of Te atoms and the reconstruction of Pt atoms (Fig. 1f). The Pt/PtTex NRs show the Pt/Te atomic ratio of 62.5:37.5 (Fig. S3b), consistent with the ICP-OES value of Pt/Te = 59.0:41.0. After electrochemical activation treatment, the atomic content of Te is reduced from 67 % to 41 %, which further confirms the dissolution of Te atoms during CV scanning. Compared to the PXRD pattern of the pristine PtTe2 NRs, a new Pt phase appears on the PXRD pattern of the Pt/PtTex NRs, indicating the formation of Pt nanoparticles on the NRs (Fig. 2a) [19,20]. Detailed TEM characterizations were performed to further study whether the Pt/PtTex heterojunction structure was formed. HRTEM image of Pt/PtTex NRs exhibits distinct lattice fringes of Pt and the PtTe2, where the lattice spacing of 0.227 and 0.289 nm were ascribed to that of Pt (111) plane and PtTe2 (101) plane, respectively (Figs. 1g and S5) [16,19]. And distinct interfaces between Pt (111) and PtTe2 (101) are observed in HRTEM images of Pt/PtTex NRs (marked with a yellow dash line), which confirms the formation of Pt/PtTex heterojunctions. The possible structural model is shown in Fig. 1e, where Pt and PtTe2 are tightly combined by forming Pt-Pt and Pt-Te bonds at the interface. The STEM-EDS elemental mappings of Pt/PtTex NRs show that Pt-rich and Te-less elements are uniformly distributed along the NRs due to Te dissolution (Fig. 1h). The above characterizations reveal the structure and morphology of the Pt/PtTex NRs where Pt NPs and PtTe2 NPs formed heterojunction during electrochemical activation. Furthermore, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on both PtTe2 NRs and Pt/PtTex NRs to track the surface chemical state and composition change (Fig. 2b and c). The peak area ratio of Pt (0)/Pt (Ⅱ) increases from 0.11 of PtTe2 NRs to 1.71 of Pt/PtTex NRs, indicating partial Pt species change from Pt (Ⅱ) to Pt (0) and thus confirming the formation of Pt nanoparticles after electrochemical activation (Table S1). Compared with Pt/C, Pt/PtTex NRs exhibit a negative shift of 0.4 eV in the binding energy of Pt (0), which is related to the charge accumulation on Pt nanoparticles caused by charge relocation at the Pt/PtTex interface (Fig. S6a). As for the XPS spectra of Te 3d, the pristine PtTe2 NRs show two doublets of Te (0) (at 583.6 and 573.1 eV) and Te (Ⅳ) (at 586.3 and 575.9 eV), respectively [17]. The Te (Ⅳ) peak of Pt/PtTex NRs shows a positive shift of 1.0 eV compared with that of PtTe2 NRs, corresponding to a decreased charge density of Te due to charge transfer at the interface. These comparisons underscore that charge relocation at the Pt/PtTex interface leads to electron transfer from the PtTe2 side to the Pt side. Moreover, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used for the Bader charge analysis and the charge difference analysis of Pt (111)/PtTe2 (101) heterojunction. As shown in Fig. S6b, a charge transfer of 2.2 e− from PtTe2 to Pt side and an obvious charge accumulation around the interfacial Pt-Pt and Pt-Te bonds were observed at the interface, which is in good agreement with the XPS analysis.

The HER performance of PtTe2 NRs and Pt/PtTex NRs were evaluated by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) curves. The Pt/PtTex NRs with different Pt contents were prepared by performing various CV cycles (100, 200, and 400 cycles) on PtTe2 NRs. The as-resulted samples are denoted as Pt/PtTex NRs-X, where X is the number of CV cycles. As shown in Figs. S7 and 8, the content of Pt increases significantly from 51.4 at%, 62.5 at% to 85.3 at% with increasing the CV cycles from 100, 200 to 400. Among the three Pt/PtTex NRs, the Pt/PtTex NRs-200 show the best HER performance in both acidic and alkaline solution, indicating that 200 CV cycles are the most suitable method to prepare the most efficient Pt/PtTex NRs towards HER. The high HER activity of Pt/PtTex NRs-200 may originate from the appropriate amount of Pt/PtTex interfaces as both high and low contents of Pt lead to the reduction of Pt/PtTex interfaces. In addition, unless otherwise specified, Pt/PtTex NRs-200 is named with Pt/PtTex NRs elsewhere in this work. In alkaline media, Pt/PtTex NRs display much better performance than commercial Pt/C while the activity of PtTe2 NRs is far inferior to that of Pt/C (Fig. 3 ). Specifically, Pt/PtTex NRs only require an extremely low overpotential of 44 mV to afford a current density of 10 mA cm−2, 26 mV lower than Pt/C (70 mV) (Fig. 3a). However, the PtTe2 NRs need a large overpotential of 416 mV to attain 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, 346 mV higher than Pt/C (70 mV). To investigate the HER catalytic kinetics of these electrocatalysts, Tafel slopes are calculated according to the Tafel equation based on the polarization curves. Remarkably, Pt/PtTex NRs exhibit an extremely low Tafel slope of 23 mV dec-1, which is only 7% of PtTe2 NRs (329 mV dec-1). The lowest Tafel slope of Pt/PtTex NRs represents the fastest catalytic kinetics of HER, which is conducive to the improvement of HER activity. In particular, the comparison of the HER performance with similar noble metal-based catalysts reported in the landmark literature indicates that Pt/PtTex NRs rank top among the outstanding

HER catalysts in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. 3c and Table S2). The HER activity of these catalysts in acidic media (0.5 H2SO4) is seen in Fig. 3d and e. The Pt/PtTex NRs exhibit an ideal HER activity with a low overpotential of 27 mV to attain 10 mA cm−2 and an unprecedented low Tafel slope of 16 mV dec-1, far superior to that of PtTe2 NRs. The comparison of HER activity with similar noble metal-based catalysts also indicates that Pt/PtTex NRs rank among the top HER catalysts in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte (Fig. 3f and Table S2).

Since the high cost of noble metals is the main factor limiting their large-scale application, the mass activity of Pt/PtTex NRs and Pt/C based on the mass of Pt are exacted and shown in Fig. 4 a and b. The mass activity of Pt/PtTex NRs is far superior to that of Pt/C. For instance, at an overpotential of 50 mV, Pt/PtTex NRs deliver the current density of 1.735 A mg−1 Pt and 0.468 A mg−1 Pt in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes, respectively, which is 19 and 5 times of commercial Pt/C (0.089 A mg−1 Pt and 0.088 A mg−1 Pt). And as the overpotential increases, the mass activity of Pt/PtTex NRs increases much faster than Pt/C. Moreover, the turnover frequencies (TOFs) based on the number of active sites of the catalyst was extracted to reflect the intrinsic activity of Pt/PtTex NRs. The Pt/PtTex NRs display much higher TOFs values than commercial Pt/C at the same potential in both acid and alkaline media (Fig. 4c and d). For example, at an overpotential of 50 mV, Pt/PtTex NRs exhibit the TOFs of 5.32 H2 s−1 and 1.43 H2 s−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes, respectively, which is 3.6 and 3.7 times of commercial Pt/C (1.46 H2 s−1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 0.38 H2 s−1 in 1.0 M KOH). And the difference in TOFs between Pt/PtTex NRs and Pt/C increases significantly as the overpotential increases, indicating an excellent intrinsic HER activity of Pt/PtTex NRs. The above comparisons with commercial Pt/C on geometric activity, mass activity, and TOFs indicate that Pt/PtTex NRs have exceptional HER performance in both acid and alkaline media, surpassing commercial Pt/C. In addition, the stability of Pt/PtTex NRs is evaluated by monitoring the required potential to maintain 20 mA cm-2 for 30 h. As shown in Fig. 3h, the potential of Pt/PtTex NRs remains stable over 30 h while a sharp increase in the required potential was observed on Pt/C after only 12 h in both alkaline and acidic media. The detailed characterization of Pt/PtTex NRs after durability reveals that the post-catalyst maintains its original shape and interfacial structure, and no obvious changes were observed in the element composition and chemical state, which accounts for good durability of Pt/PtTex NRs (Figs. S9 and 10).

Since the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) is tightly connected with the electrocatalytic activity and positively correlated with the double-layer capacitance (Cdl), the ECSA comparison is first performed by comparing the Cdl values of catalysts [21]. Pt/PtTex NRs show a higher Cdl value than PtTe2 NRs, indicating a more exposed reactive surface of Pt/PtTex NRs (Fig. S11). Furthermore, CO stripping method, an ideal method to quantitatively determine the ECSA for Pt-based catalysts, was carried out on these catalysts (Fig. S12) [22–24]. The corresponding results reveal that the ECSA of Pt/PtTex NRs (78 m2 g−1 Pt) is much larger than that of Pt/C (56 m2 g−1 Pt) (Fig. 3g). Moreover, the number of active sites was also extracted here from CO stripping measurement [24,25]. As is seen in Fig. 3g, the number of active sites of Pt/PtTex NRs is 1.4 times that of Pt/C, indicating Pt/PtTex NRs have more active sites. Both more active sites and larger ECSA of Pt/PtTex NRs may benefit from the charge relocation and structural deformation at Pt/PtTex interfaces. As Pt/PtTex NRs exhibit much higher intrinsic activity with larger TOFs than Pt/C, valence band (VB)-XPS measurement was further carried out to determine the d-band center of catalyst, which is an effective way to predict and describe the adsorption of intermediates [26,27]. Compared with Pt/C, the Pt/PtTex NRs show a significant upshift of 1.07 eV on the d-band center, indicating the OH* adsorption of Pt/PtTex NRs may be greatly enhanced and thus improve the kinetics of water dissociation in alkaline HER (Fig. S13). As is well known, the layered structure of PtTe2 makes it difficult to transfer charge between layers and thus lead to unfavorable activity in electrocatalytic reaction [17]. The formed Pt/PtTex heterojunction may improve the charge transfer between PtTe2 layers through the newly formed Pt-Pt or Pt-Te bonds at the interface. To verify this, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements of PtTe2 NRs and Pt/PtTex NRs were conducted in both 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH solutions, and the resulted Nyquist plots are shown in Fig. S14b–d. The charge transfer resistance (Rct) of Pt/PtTex NRs is only about 1/10 and 1/50 of PtTe2 NRs in alkaline and acidic media, respectively, revealing that the formed Pt/PtTex interface does improve the charge transfer of PtTe2 NRs to a great extent. Therefore, EIS confirms that the formation of the heterojunction is beneficial to improve the electron transfer property of PtTe2 NRs. Furthermore, the density of states (DOS) was calculated to investigate the conductivity (Figs. S14a and S15). Compared with PtTe2, the DOS of Pt/PtTex NRs around the Fermi level has been greatly increased, indicating the formation of heterojunction has significantly improved the conductivity.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Analysis of HER activity by DFT calculations
ce:section.ce:para: In terms of alkaline HER, it is reported that OH* adsorption is proportional to the water dissociation capacity, thereby affecting its activity [11]. To explore the OH* adsorption at the Pt/PtTex interface, the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of OH* (ΔGOH*) was determined at both sides of the Pt/PtTex interface (Figs. 5 a and S16). For easy distinction, the active site on the Pt side is named Site 1 and that on the PtTe2 side is named Site 2. Compared with Pt (ΔGOH*: 1.36 eV) and PtTe2 (ΔGOH*: 0.75 eV), the Pt/PtTex shows more negative ΔGOH* values (-0.10 eV on Site 1 and -0.40 eV on Site 2), indicating a stronger OH* adsorption of Pt/PtTex. The significant enhancement of ΔGOH* on both sides of the Pt/PtTex interface demonstrates that the formed Pt/PtTex heterojunction can indeed improve OH* adsorption ability for favorable water dissociation in alkaline media. In terms of HER in acidic media, ΔGH* is generally employed as the ideal activity descriptor. As revealed by the positive ΔGH* (0.09 eV) value of PtTe2 (101) and negative ΔGH* (-0.10 eV) value of Pt (111), it can be found that PtTe2 shows weak adsorption ability towards H* and Pt exhibits strong H* adsorption (Figs. 5b and S17–18). In contrast, Pt/PtTex shows an ideal ΔGH* of -0.01 eV on Site 1 and 0.03 eV on Site 2, which are closer to the thermodynamic neutral ΔGH* (0 eV) of ideal HER catalysts. The moderate hydrogen adsorption of Pt/PtTex endows it with favorable reaction thermodynamics for HER, which agrees well with the experimental results that Pt/PtTex NRs show much better HER activity than Pt and PtTe2 in acidic media. Therefore, the formation of Pt/PtTex heterojunction not only enhances the OH* adsorption ability but also optimizes the H* adsorption, endowing the hybrid material with excellent HER performance in both alkaline and acidic media.

To investigate the adsorption of intermediates on Pt/PtTex NRs from the experiment, we performed cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements on Pt/PtTex NRs. And CV curves of Pt/C were also obtained for comparison as commercial Pt/C is generally employed as a benchmark catalyst. For Pt-based catalysts, it is reported that CO stripping can be employed to reflect OH* adsorption behavior [2,28]. As shown in Fig. 5c, the CO stripping peak of Pt/PtTex NRs is centered at 0.817 V, which is 29 mV lower than that of Pt/C (0.846 V). The lower CO stripping peak potential of Pt/PtTex NRs reflects that Pt/PtTex NRs have a stronger OH* adsorption capacity compared to Pt/C. Furthermore, we correlate the CO stripping peak potentials with ΔGOH* predicated by DFT calculations and shown in Fig. 5d. The two evaluations of OH* adsorption showed consistent trends. Both the CO stripping peak potentials and ΔGOH* of Pt/PtTex NRs are lower than Pt/C, revealing enhanced OH* adsorption on Pt/PtTex NRs, which is crucial to promote water dissociation. Under-potential deposition of hydrogen (Hupd) has been regarded as an indicator to reflect H* adsorption-desorption behavior on Pt-based catalysts in HER tests [11]. Here, the Hupd of Pt/C and Pt/PtTex NRs is determined from CV curves (Fig. 5e). The Hupd peak of Pt/C is located at 0.113 V for (110) facet and 0.186 V for (100) facet. And the Hupd peak of Pt/PtTex NRs is centered at 0.094 V and 0.155 V, which is 19 mV and 31 mV lower than that of Pt (110) and Pt (100), respectively. The more negative Hupd desorption peak potential of Pt/PtTex NRs indicates that the H* adsorption on Pt/PtTex NRs is weaker than that on Pt/C. This finding is well consistent with the trend obtained from ΔGH* in DFT calculations (Fig. 5f). Therefore, the good agreement between the potential obtained from the CV curve and the ΔG predicated from the DFT calculations reveals that the formed Pt/PtTex heterojunction strengthens the adsorption of OH* for favorable dissociation of water, and at the same time weakens the adsorption of H* on both sides of the interface, making it in a thermally neutral state, which is conducive to the generation of hydrogen.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Analysis of intermediates adsorption from the electronic structure of catalysts
ce:section.ce:para: The variation of OH* and H* adsorption on Pt/PtTex was further investigated from the perspective of electronic structure. Here, the projected density of state (pDOS), projected Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (pCOHP), and the partial charge density were employed to evaluate the Pt-H and Pt-OH interaction on Pt/PtTex surface models [29–33]. The molecular orbital of OH shows that 2σ and π orbitals are located in the outermost layer at the O end (Figs. S19–20). Therefore, the d orbital of Pt will first interact with the 2σ and π orbitals to form the Pt-O bond. The pDOS of Pt and O show that the peaks of π orbital and d orbital overlap well in the energy windows of [-6, -3] and [-3, 0] eV (Fig. S21), which can be assigned to the bonding states and antibonding states, respectively. Furthermore, the pDOS of π orbitals (px+py and pz) reveal that the π orbital antibonding states of these models are mainly contributed by px+py orbitals of the O atom. However, the bonding states of π orbital are different in these models. As the px+py orbitals are the main components of π orbital, their participation in the formation of bonding states is conducive to the formation of a stable Pt-O bond (Fig. 6 ). For Pt (111), the pz orbital mainly contributes to the bonding states in the π orbitals, resulting in weak Pt-OH interaction. However, the bonding state of π orbital on Site 1 of Pt/PtTex is contributed by px+py and pz orbitals, indicating the formation of stable Pt-O bond is more favored on Site 1. In terms of PtTe2, bonding states of π orbital consist of px+py and partial pz orbitals. Differently, the bonding states of π orbital on Site 2 of Pt/PtTex are all contributed by px+py orbitals, indicating a stronger Pt-O interaction. Moreover, the partial charge densities show that the bonding interaction between Pt and O on Pt (111) is mainly along the z-axis and the px+py orbitals are less involved (Fig. S22). Site 1 of Pt/PtTex shows that the bonding interaction between Pt and O is both along the z-direction and in the xy plane, which is more favorable for the hybridization of π and d orbital (Fig. S23). Compared with PtTe2 (101) (Fig. S24), the Pt-O bonding states on Site 2 of Pt/PtTex are predominantly in the xy plane, thus favoring hybridization between the px+py orbital of O atom and the d orbital of Pt atom, leading to strong Pt-O interactions (Fig. S25). Therefore, both the pDOS and partial charge density results reveal a stronger interaction between Pt and O atoms on Pt/PtTex than on Pt (111) and PtTe2 (101), indicating that the formation of heterojunction does enhance the OH adsorption on both sides of the interface. The Pt-O interaction was further quantitatively analyzed by COHP curves (Figs. S26–27). The ICOHP of Pt-O on Pt/PtTex (-1.55 eV on Site 1 and -1.90 eV on Site 2) is more negative than that on Pt (111) (-1.31 eV) and PtTe2 (101) (-1.40 eV), indicating Pt-O hybridization interaction on Pt/PtTex is enhanced. Furthermore, partial COHP (pCOHP) results reveal that the adsorption of OH* is mainly achieved through 5d-2p interaction and thus the d band center of Pt can be employed to predict the Pt-OH interaction. Therefore, the ΔGOH* and ICOHP results agree well with the OH* adsorption predicted by the d-band center in VB-XPS. In terms of the variation of the H adsorption ability on the Pt/PtTex, partial charge densities in the energy window of [0.00, 6.00] eV are first extracted. The unoccupied H 1 s orbital on Site 1 has a smaller spatial extension than that on Pt (111), indicating that the H atoms on Pt/PtTex have fewer electrons flowing back to the metal surface after adsorption, thus possibly leading to weaker Pt-H interactions on Pt/PtTex (Figs. S28–32). Compared with PtTe2 (101), a little larger spatial extension of the unoccupied H 1 s orbital on Site 2 indicates that the H adsorption may be enhanced. Moreover, the pDOS of H after adsorption show that the bonding states of H on Site 1 of Pt/PtTex are more localized than on Pt (111), revealing a weaker Pt-H orbital interaction on Pt/PtTex. The bonding states of H on PtTe2 (101) and Site 2 of Pt/PtTex are both localized but the energy of bonding states on the latter is more negative, which indicates that the Pt-H interaction on Site 2 is improved. Furthermore, the Pt-H interaction on these surface models is quantitatively analyzed by COHP analysis (Figs. S33–34). More positive ICOHP values of Pt-H on Site 1 (-1.03 eV) than that on Pt (111) (-1.25 eV) indicate that the Pt-H interaction is reduced on Pt/PtTex. Compared with PtTe2 (101), the ICOHP values of Pt-H on Site 2 (-0.92 eV) decrease by 0.14 eV, which indicates that the orbital interaction is enhanced. The COHP of 5d-1s and 6s-1s orbitals reveals that 5d-1 s hybridization interaction is dominant in the Pt-H bonding states of Pt (111) and Site 2. However, both 5d-1s and 6s-1s hybridization interactions have a large proportion on PtTe2 (101) and Site 1, which is due to the matched orbital symmetry between H and Pt. In this case, the d-band center is not suitable for predicting the Pt-H interaction since the 5d-1s interaction is not the major interaction in the Pt-H adsorption. As a result, the results of ΔGH* and ICOHP are not consistent with the adsorption of intermediates predicted by the d-band center in VB-XPS, where the H* adsorption of Pt/PtTex NRs is weaker than that of Pt/C, although the d-band center of Pt/PtTex NRs is closer to the Fermi energy level.

In summary, Pt/PtTex NRs are synthesized by a facile electrochemical activation of PtTe2 NRs to guide the formation of Pt/PtTex heterojunctions for intermediate adsorption modulation of HER. Based on the experiment results and DFT calculations, the ΔGH* at both sides of the Pt/PtTex interface is regulated to the thermodynamic neutral value of 0 eV. The adsorption ability of OH* at the interface was significantly improved, which promote the dissociation of water on Pt/PtTex NRs and result in a significant improvement in alkaline HER activity. Taking Pt/PtTex NRs as a highly efficient and stable electrocatalyst for both acid and alkaline HER, the optimal Pt/PtTex NRs show 19 and 5 times the mass activity of commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1.0 M KOH electrolytes at an overpotential of 50 mV, respectively. Moreover, Pt/PtTex NRs show good stability of more than 30 h due to the stable Pt/PtTex interface.

Jiadong Chen: Methodology, Data curation, DFT Calculations, Writing original draft preparation. Minkai Qin: Methodology, Data curation, Investigation. Shuangxiu Ma: DFT Calculations, Data curation. Ruxue Fan: Data curation, Discussion. Xiaozhong Zheng: Data curation, Discussion. Shanjun Mao: Data curation, Discussion. Chunhong Chen: Data curation, Discussion. Yong Wang: Supervision, Conceptualization, Writing- Reviewing and Editing.
